fields.name: Color Contrast Still Ignored in 2025?
fields.description: I’ve noticed a lot of modern websites still use very low-contrast text—light grey on white, tiny font sizes, or text embedded inside gradient backgrounds. It’s becoming frustrating, especially for users with low vision or even just anyone reading under bright sunlight. Has anyone found good tools or browser extensions that reliably fix contrast issues on any site?

fields.name: VoiceOver Suddenly Lagging on iOS 18?
fields.description: Since updating to iOS 18, VoiceOver feels slower when navigating large lists (like Messages or Contacts). I’m not sure if it’s a bug or if I need to tweak settings. Anyone else having this issue or found a workaround?

fields.name: Accessible Event Spaces: Why Is It Still So Hard?
fields.description: I attended a tech meetup last week and the venue had no ramp, dim lighting, and the mic kept cutting out. For a 2025 event in a major city, this felt embarrassing. What standards should event planners follow, and how do we encourage organizers to take accessibility seriously?

fields.name: Captions on Social Media Videos Are All Over the Place
fields.description: Auto-generated captions have gotten better, but they still miss slang, accents, and background sounds. For Deaf users or even people watching in noisy places, this can make content hard to follow. Do content creators need more tools, or are platforms just not trying hard enough?

fields.name: Why Some Websites Still Break Screen Readers in 2025
fields.description: Several users have noticed that even modern websites still ship with elements that block or confuse screen readers. Examples include buttons made from <div> tags without labels, infinite scrolling lists that never announce new items, and forms that fail to expose required fields properly. This discussion asks why these issues keep recurring and what developers can do to adopt truly inclusive practices.

fields.name: Public Transport Apps and Cognitive Load for Neurodivergent Users
fields.description: Some transit apps overwhelm users with crowded maps, multiple layers of UI, or rapid pop-up suggestions. Neurodivergent users—especially those with ADHD or processing-related disabilities—often struggle to filter the important information quickly. This discussion asks how travel and mapping apps can reduce cognitive load through simplified modes, consistent layouts, and predictable navigation flows.
